results.title: Stretch away stress
results.creator_credit: ABC-TV (Australia), Gillian Ross and Samantha Livingstone
results.brief_description: In today’s busy lifestyles, stress plays an unnecessarily large role in people lives. This video attempts to address the problem by presenting two half hour self nurturing sessions. Yoga teacher Dr Gillian Ross will guide the viewer through stretches and yoga postures, meditative pauses, with constant attention to deep breathing and the release of tension. Provide your body with a tonic for the whole body.

results.title: Stress: your own worst enemy
results.creator_credit: Churchill Films, Fiveson Productions and Robert S. Fiveson
results.brief_description: The film examines stress in biological, social and emotional terms and outlines various methods for overcoming its health-threatening effects. Aided by interpretations from stress specialists, the film focuses principally on how different people experience and cope with stress in their daily lives. Several less conventional ways in which people cope with stress are shown: a company recreation project, a community sports program, meditation, yoga, Tai Chi, acupuncture and biofeedback. The film concludes by describing some of the tell-tale signs of stress, and encouraging sufferers to take action.

results.title: Stress: parents with a handicapped child
results.creator_credit: Derrick Knight and Partners and Bernice Rubens
results.brief_description: Illustrates the difficulties created for parents by mental and physical defects of children. Five children handicapped in different ways are shown in their family situations and their parents discuss their problems.

results.title: Stress: A Personal Challenge (TEFC)
results.brief_description: This vide shows the way stress manifests itself mentally and physically, and presents some of the everyday gestures which may indicate stress. It highlights an individual, personal approach to dealing with stress; and how to control it and be turned to one’s advantage.

results.title: Stress, health and you (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Neil Mawby Productions and Herbert Long
results.brief_description: Deals with stress and its effect on our health. Dr. Selye discusses how stress can have both positive and negative causes. An overview that helps people to analyse how their own health is modified by stressful events.

results.title: Stress management: wedding daze
results.creator_credit: Paramount Communications, A. Scott Miller and Robert Boucher
results.brief_description: Follows the members of a wedding party on the day of the wedding and shows their various reactions to the stresses under which they are placed. Points out that negative reactions to stress can be avoided and suggests how to accomplish this. Suitable for upper secondary and teacher/tertiary levels.

results.title: Stress busters
results.brief_description: This presentation demonstrates Amanda Gore’s easy style of education and entertainment. Her unique humorous style, and passion for messages facilitates behavioural changes and creates rapport with any group, no matter what size. With a background in physiotherapy, psychology and neurolinguistics, she specialises in creativity and new ways of thinking, state of the art selling skils, lifestyle, communication, stress management and relationships. She talks about the how rather than the why, which gives people the skills and motivates them to make behavioural changes. Her constant research means every presentation is fresh. In this video Amanda aims to change your way of thinking about stress in the workplace and at home. She tries to make her audience see that it is a matter of attitude and know-how. This videotape was recorded at the FMRC (Financial Management Research Centre), Armidale, N.S.W. during a a Management Forum for Accountants in May 1993.

results.title: Stress and you: relaxation techniques (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Neil Mawby Productions and Herbert Long
results.brief_description: The human body is a complex network of rhythms that enable us to move grow and adapt. Only when we understand these rhythms can we understand stress and combat it accordingly. Biofeedback, relaxation response and meditation are demonstrated as means of reducing daily tension.
